channel.title: Buzzing on The Wall Street Journal
channel.description: 用中文浏览华尔街日报热门报道

item.title: Secretary of State Antony Blinken said preliminary reports indicate that Russia is deliberately targeting civilians as part of its invasion of Ukraine—allegations that if true would amount to war crimes under international law https://t.co/LeqRFLMRFb
Western sanctions on Russia could prove less effective if China offers Moscow access to what some see as the bazaar of choice for rogue nations https://t.co/dxl9fGecf9
From @WSJopinion: Western democracies have culpably failed to boost their military capability while indulging acts of economic and cultural self-harm, writes @HonTonyAbbott https://t.co/s9zXFPr7pM

Russian police detained thousands of people protesting the war in Ukraine Sunday, as the Kremlin—which has banned Facebook and Twitter and shut down independent media—moved to silence any dissent against the military operations https://t.co/z0fSlVj84v

The U.N. atomic agency said Sunday that staff at Ukraine’s largest nuclear plant were now under orders from the commander of Russian forces there, and that communication channels between the plant and Ukraine’s nuclear regulator had sharply reduced https://t.co/iv032f0yEm

Russian banks that have been cut off from global payments networks are turning to China’s state-owned UnionPay system as the country tries to sidestep boycotts by Western businesses https://t.co/HQJqxEsK2Q
French President Emmanuel Macron urged Russian President Vladimir Putin to ensure the protection and security of Ukraine’s nuclear sites in a phone call Sunday https://t.co/KxtmSL58oa

Investors are starting to buy Ukrainian and Russian bonds that plummeted to discounted prices, betting that they will recover if the war between the two countries comes to an end https://t.co/xQJ00aunBy
The skyrocketing price of oil has President Biden facing a quandary: He'll be unable to respond to calls to ban Russian imports without risking even higher prices at the pump. https://t.co/S0zA1Nlu9L
Ukrainian fighters wounded while battling the Russian invasion will be treated in hospitals in Germany and Poland, officials from both countries said Sunday https://t.co/J7aBq5L2kr

“The armed forces of Ukraine are now, at least on the European continent, the only armed forces that have permanent eight-year combat experience,” said Yurii Biriukov, a former adviser to the Ukrainian president. “Now here is the result.” https://t.co/qLlPa953g5

“Beyond Putin, this is very damning for one person in particular, and that is Sergei Shoigu." Russia’s defense chief modernized its armed forces, but their failure to quickly seize Ukraine has shown he didn’t create the fighting machine he touted. https://t.co/NktFLpNdHk
The U.S. and European partners are discussing a ban on imports of Russian oil, Secretary of State Anthony Blinken said Sunday https://t.co/BczZw2pb6R

In Kherson, the only regional capital that Russia has conquered since it unleashed the war on Ukraine, thousands of people came out for the third day of protests against the occupation, waving Ukrainian flags https://t.co/ODf8J0yvm7

On Sunday, Ukrainian authorities said they had to abandon efforts to evacuate civilians from the southern city of Mariupol, for the second day in a row, saying Russia shelled the southeastern port city as evacuation convoys were gathering https://t.co/4757RDmJFH
It's important to adjust your workouts when you hit 50. Here are some exercises to help keep you strong and safe into the decades to come. https://t.co/PuLfHAEbj8

Pope Francis on Sunday deplored the “rivers of blood and tears” flowing in Ukraine, using his strongest language yet to criticize the war, though he stopped short of blaming Russia https://t.co/W5vsu2gZSY
Russian forces shelled Ukrainian civilians trying to escape a Kyiv suburb, and a second evacuation attempt from southeast cities failed https://t.co/WQlsbmeYm7
Kyiv is making a second attempt to evacuate civilians from its besieged cities saying a cease-fire is set after accusing Moscow of resuming attacks on residential areas https://t.co/Kry2FXdWwl
Here's what to know about Russian oligarchs and why they're facing heightened scrutiny by Western governments amid the Ukraine crisis https://t.co/dVBrjHPQdf

From @WSJopinion: Putin’s isolation and miscalculation make him dangerous but they also make him vulnerable, writes @HolmanJenkins. His regime is destroying itself over a fictional threat of NATO aggression. https://t.co/PpB1NrmVoe
Here's what to know about Russian oligarchs and why they're facing heightened scrutiny by Western governments amid the Ukraine crisis https://t.co/CuKJJbT0U4
War trade: Hedge funds are buying Ukraine and Russia bonds for cents on the dollar. https://t.co/cYnroVn3gG
Western sanctions on Russia could prove less effective if China offers Moscow access to what some see as the bazaar of choice for rogue nations https://t.co/1GuA6K8D3N
Russian metals giant Norilsk Nickel, a key supplier of nickel and palladium, might be too big to sanction https://t.co/OyNjPj8Wq5
Italy seizes Russian oligarchs’ yachts and villas. The most valuable was the yacht Lady M, estimated to be worth some 65 million euros. https://t.co/wJdWmsyC8c
News from the Ukraine battlefront some 5,000 miles away has dominated headlines and airwaves in Taiwan—and spurred new interest in battle readiness https://t.co/pMCZGFra44
Nuclear weapons were once thought to deter conventional conflict. Now Russia is using them to shield its aggression—an example China is watching. https://t.co/QY9zXvyhdt

Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky brought up instituting a no-fly zone over Ukraine, but said, through a translator, “if you can’t do that, at least get me planes,” according to a person on the call. https://t.co/ewS9VpWmna
On paper, China’s banks and its homegrown payments system could offer Russia respite from crippling Western sanctions. In practice, it isn’t that simple. https://t.co/ihSHE3zxZL
How thermobaric weapons work https://t.co/8oDBZKEQU0
In the cobblestoned city of Lviv, resisting Russia was part of the local folklore. Now they're making Molotov cocktails out of craft-beer bottles. https://t.co/Zx4ZdZZX44
Canada is opening its doors to an unlimited number of Ukrainians fleeing Russia’s invasion https://t.co/zZu7z7T1dC
Here's what to know about Russian oligarchs and why they're facing heightened scrutiny by Western governments amid the Ukraine crisis https://t.co/9LTbTmJnbM

Visa and Mastercard are suspending their Russian operations. Among the debit and credit cards issued in Russia, Visa and Mastercard cards accounted for 74% of payment transactions in the country in 2020. https://t.co/XVXWO1sd4k
In 1862, Congress made paper money legal tender for all debts. What started as a way of paying for the Civil War ended up transforming the American economy. https://t.co/qEAfNhWnOn
The U.S. National Park Service has roots in the democratic idea that natural beauty should be preserved for public enjoyment. https://t.co/F84sQ9g6XQ
The U.S. is exploring a deal in which Poland would send Soviet-era aircraft to Ukraine in return for American F-16 jet fighters https://t.co/JV8E9aD9iB

The parents of Katie Meyer, the Stanford University soccer team captain who was found dead in a dormitory this week, said that a potential disciplinary action from the university might have contributed to her death https://t.co/2kucK9vqMl

From @WSJopinion: The Biden administration should see this conflict for what it is: a big Russian mistake, writes @ProfessorHannah. Putin’s overconfident assessment of his own power has been matched by his underestimation of Ukrainian resolve. https://t.co/uffT9dTFWl
Russia’s war on Ukraine has unleashed auto makers’ third supply-chain crisis in as many years https://t.co/K9FzCTRx7b
Wheat futures are at their highest levels since the global financial crisis, amid Russia’s war in Ukraine #WSJWhatsNow https://t.co/7DRg459mPi https://t.co/NCg8YghicW
Naftali Bennett’s meeting with Vladimir Putin took place with the blessing of the U.S. administration, the Israeli prime minister’s office said. https://t.co/tPZF4GqtXY

Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky asked for assistance in obtaining more lethal military aid—especially Russian-made jet fighters that Ukrainian pilots can fly—and supported a proposal to ban U.S. imports of Russian oil. https://t.co/HLwYvLkVVI

Aeroflot-Russian Airlines said it is suspending almost all international flights in response to government instructions, increasing Russia’s isolation from the global air transport system https://t.co/yZrWN5vnuC

From @WSJopinion: Ukraine’s fight for survival ought to give us some pause from the hysterical tenor of our domestic political debate, writes @gerardtbaker. It’s a reminder that freedom isn’t something we can take for granted. https://t.co/fkEYdaTy5z

Italian police said they seized a number of yachts and villas scattered around the country from wealthy Russian individuals targeted by European Union sanctions following Russia’s invasion of Ukraine https://t.co/pggcsF4GKa
“An awkward nexus.” Xi Jinping and Vladimir Putin presented a united front against the U.S. on Feb. 4. That’s now proving a problem for China. https://t.co/FPDOgg46SD

U.S. drug regulators approved a new customized, cell-based treatment for blood cancer from Johnson & Johnson that is the first such therapy in the U.S. to be developed initially in China https://t.co/sJTmbUumgM

Broadcasters around the world are buying the rights to “Servant of the People,” an old TV show starring Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky as the Ukrainian president #WSJWhatsNow https://t.co/KjIVhYDGXU https://t.co/ncRTLkNkX1
